description.narrative:
Oxfam in Vietnam and Spark Center for Social Entrepreneurship Development have been engaged in conceptualizing a Strengthen Resilience Options by Narrowing the Gaps (STRONG) for agribusiness in Vietnam that is the continual of the pilot activities which were implemented in 2015-2016.
The STRONG project aims at building resilience to disaster and climate risks for private agri-businesses and service providers for agricultural production and services, including insurance companies. The project will create impact on the sustainable livelihood for small-scale producers and processors as final beneficiaries.
The STRONG comprises of two phases: Pilot (Awakening) and Growing (Roll out). The focus of the pilot phase is on raising agribusiness awareness on climate resilience and developing their business resilience capacity while promoting inclusive business models to create benefits for both companies and smallholder farmers in their supply chain. Apart from working with SMEs and also microbusiness in the agriculture sector, the STRONG project in the period September 2016-March 2017 started identifying and working with interested institutions for providing support and services to SMEs in this regard. Specifically, it develops the capacity of interested individual and organizations in provinces that can provide support to SMEs in climate resilience as well as engaging with financial service providers, specifically TYM, a micro financial institution to review and improve their credit assessment and monitoring tools that can help their clients, being micro businesses and small producers to identify potential climate risks. Experience from STRONG project so far has shown that:
(i) Enforce SME practices for climate risk resilience in the agriculture needs adequate support structure at local level to deliver suitable services and support to SMEs such as mentoring, connecting to relevant actors. Important partners could be local research and agriculture promotion centres, social # political organizations such as women and/or youth unions, NGOs, both local and int#l ones, operating in the areas with private SMEs participation, etc. (ii) Working with financial institutions on possible products and loan approval and monitoring tools for SME climate risk resilience could bring substantial benefits for service providers as well as their clients (SMEsand small holder farmers). However, it could take time to work with large commercial banks due to the complexity in its operation arrangement. Therefore, exploring and engaging with innovative financial institutions, which are eager to introduce new products/services are more effective.
(iii) Advocacy work for policy recommendations will be more effective once evidences from SMEs, service practices related to disaster and climate risk resilience gathered and analysed. With government national program for natural disaster damage prevention and other int#l development initiative targeting climate change issues in the agriculture sector, such as programs conducted byDFAT and SNV, Asian Foundation, World Vision for example, there is a need to find channels to trigger high-level attention advocacy for the project. This will help creating more confidence and local supports for private sector to be creative in climate resilience while enhancing the livelihoods for smallholder farmers and processor.

participating-org.narrative:
Co-founded in early 2010, the Center for Social Entrepreneurship Development (Spark) was part of SNV global program on Local Capacity Development Facility. In 2011, it became a Vietnamese not-for-profit organization under Vietnam Union of Science and Technology Associations. Spark's aim is to resolve social issues in Vietnam through supporting sustainable growth of social enterprises and inclusive business and facilitating local service market for business and development needs. Spark's activities It activities include programs-based and consultancy services. a. Social Entrepreneurship Development Program To address capacity gap and lack of access to finance for social enterprises Spark identifies and selects promising businesses with innovative business solutions addressing social issues at local level through open calls for proposal and competitive selection process. Business assessment and long term mentoring is provided to enable supported organizations to implement their up-scaling solutions successfully and prepare them to be ready for financing. Spark connects them to potential investors and service providers for growth their businesses. Over the past 4 years, Spark has engaged with almost 295 social enterprises and 50 inclusive business companies. 19 social enterprises of various sizes and in different stages of business development in different sectors have received seed funding and incubation services from Spark. b. Service Market Development for local business and development needs Program Local companies and other users have limited access to quality and affordable services due to the lack of understanding on types of services available and its quality in the markets and as well the needs of end users. Spark helps to bridge this gap by facilitating the development of service markets at the provincial level through organising market place events where local service providers and users or sector can meet and discuss the needs of users and service available and come to service deals. It also facilitates professional learning for service providers: promoting learning activities among service providers to grasp market opportunities, and refine their products or services to respond to local users and raise awareness of quality standards in service provision. Spark has organized 11 market places in 7 provinces with the participation of about 170 service providers and 510 users. 190 service deals have been generated with a total value of $US 290.000. Of which 55% has turned into commercial contract. 3. Consultancy services: Spark delivers consultancy services such as sector research, evaluation, business assessment or mentoring for NGOs and business.
Staffing and governance structure. There are currently 4 full-time staff working at Spark (excluding one staff is on study leave). Spark is steered by its governing board comprised by 3 founding organisations (SNV, Center for Community Support Development Studies (CECODES) and Center for Sustainable Rural Development (SRD) and 2 individualsfrom business sector.
SPARK Center for Social Entrepreneu Development
